title: Proposed law could limit nicotine in e-cigs in US in attempt to 'epidemic' of teen vaping addiction
text:
A US congressman has introduced a bill that would put a limit on the amount of nicotine allowed in e-cigarettes.

The bill, introduced on Monday by Rep Raja Krishnamoorthi (D-IL), is called the END ENDS Act, or the Ending Nicotine Dependence from Electronic Nicotine Delivery Systems Act.

It would allow no more than 20 milligrams per milliliter (mg/mL) in liquid pods that are used in e-cigarettes.

Although nicotine levels can vary from brand to brand, JUUL pods - the leading brand of e-cigs - currently contain 59 mg/mL in a standard pod, nearly three times as much as the proposed amount.

The bill would also allow the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to lower the cap even further if deemed necessary.

Krishnamoorthi says limiting the amount of nicotine will make e-cigarettes 'less addictive and appealing' to teen users, and hopefully help curb the youth vaping epidemic that has been rising in recent years.

US Rep Raja Krishnamoorthi (D-IL) introduced a bill on Monday that would allow no more than 20 milligrams per milliliter in liquid pods used in e-cigarettes. Pictured: Krishnamoorthi (center) speaks alongside Rep Peter King (left), R-NY, and other Representatives at a press conference on stopping youth vaping, September 2019

Several countries around the world have nicotine caps, including the UK, Israel and the European Union.

Supporters of e-cigarette companies like JUUL say the pods help smokers transition from traditional cigarettes.

But critics say the pods are highly addictive and that high nicotine concentrations are partly responsible for the rising rates of teen vapers.

E-cigarettes are currently the most used tobacco product among US teens.

The 2016 Surgeon General's report found a 900 percent increase in e-cigarette use among young people from 2011 to 2015.

In September, a report from FDA found that 27.5 percent of high school students are using e-cigarettes in 2019.

'As a concerned parent, I am committed to preventing a new generation of nicotine addicts,' Krishnamoorthi, the chairman of the House Oversight Subcommittee on Economic and Consumer Policy, said in a statement.

'Capping the concentration of nicotine in e-cigarettes is integral to ending the youth vaping epidemic by making these products less addictive, less appealing to youth, and less harmful to public health.

It comes on the heels of an investigation into a slew of breathing illnesses related to vaping across the country

There have been 1,080 cases reported in mostly teens and young adults in 48 states, according to a Centers for Disease Control and Prevention report released on Thursday.

At least 20 deaths, which have been suspected to be linked to vaping, have been reported in 17 states: Alabama, California, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Kansas, Michigan, Minnesota, Mississippi, Missouri, Nebraska, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Oregon and Virginia.

In response, several states have temporarily restricted or banned flavored tobacco products.

In September 2019, Michigan became the first state to ban all flavored e-cigarettes, including menthol.

New York and Rhode Island quickly followed suit, and Washington State's ban is set to take effect later this month.

Meanwhile Massachusetts has gone the farthest, issuing a four-month ban on all vaping products - flavored or not.

President Donald Trump has also announced his administration's plans to ban flavored vaping products nationwide.
